column1: |480 u.s. 1|"Burlington Northern Railroad Co. v. Woods
An Alabama statute requires an appellate court
column2: upon affirming a money judgment without substantial modification
column3: to impose a 10% penalty on any appellant who had obtained a stay of that judgment by executing a bond.  The statute's purposes are to penalize frivolous appeals and those interposed for delay
column4: and to provide appellees with additional compensation for having to suffer the ordeal of appeal.  Upon affirming without modification a judgment for respondents in their federal diversity action arising from a motorcycle accident
column5: the Eleventh Circuit imposed the Alabama statute's penalty on petitioner
column6: which had posted bond to stay the judgment pending appeal.

column1: Held:  The Alabama mandatory affirmance penalty statute has no application to judgments entered by federal courts sitting in diversity.  Pp.  480 U. S. 3-8.

(a) Rule 38 of the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure affords federal courts of appeals plenary discretion to award damages to an appellee upon determining that the appeal is frivolous.  Federal Rule 38's discretionary mode of operation conflicts with the Alabama statute's mandatory operation.  Furthermore
column2: the purposes underlying Rule 38 -- to penalize frivolous appeals and to compensate injured appellees for the delay and added expense inherent therein -- are sufficiently coextensive with the statute's purposes to indicate that the Rule occupies the statute's field of operation.  The fact that Alabama has a similar Appellate

column1: Rule coexisting with the statute does not mean that a federal court could impose the mandatory statutory penalty while remaining free to exercise its Federal Rule 38 discretionary authority
column2: since the statute would improperly limit the exercise of that discretion in instances in which the court wished to impose a penalty of less than 10%.  Pp.  480 U. S. 4-8.

column1: (b) Rule 38 must be applied under the analysis set forth in Hanna v. Plumer
column3: since (a) it is a constitutional exercise of rulemaking authority in that it regulates matters that can reasonably be classified as procedural
column4: and (b) it affects only the process of enforcing litigants' rights
column5: and not the rights themselves
column6: and therefore does not violate the Rule Enabling Act's prohibition against affecting substantive rights (28 U.S.C. 2072).  P.  480 U. S. 8.

column2: J.
column3: delivered the opinion for a unanimous Court.

column2: and requires that any expenditure for such purpose be financed by voluntary contributions to a separate segregated fund.  Appellee is a nonprofit

column4: whose purpose is to foster respect for human life and to defend the right to life of all human beings
column5: born and unborn
column6: through educational
column7: political
column8: and other forms of activities.  To further this purpose
column9: it has published a newsletter that has been distributed to contributors and to noncontributors who have expressed support for the organization.  In September
column11: appellee prepared and distributed a ""Special Edition"" exhorting readers to vote ""pro-life"" in the upcoming primary elections in Massachusetts
column12: listing the candidates for each state and federal office in every voting district in the State
column13: and identifying each one as either supporting or opposing appellee's views.  While some 400 candidates were listed
column14: the photographs of only 13 were featured
column15: all of whom were identified as favoring appellee's views.  The publication was prepared by a staff that had prepared no regular newsletter
column16: was distributed to a much larger audience than that of the regular newsletter
column17: most of whom were members of the general public
column18: and was financed by money taken from appellee's general treasury funds.  A complaint was filed with appellant Federal Election Commission (FEC) alleging that the ""Special Edition"" violated  316 as representing an expenditure of funds from a corporate treasury to distribute to the general public a campaign flyer on behalf of certain political candidates.  After the FEC determined that there was probable cause to believe that appellee had violated the statute
column19: the FEC filed a complaint in Federal District Court
column20: seeking a civil penalty and other relief.  The District Court granted appellee's motion for summary judgment
column21: holding that  316 did not apply to appellee
column24: was unconstitutional as a violation of the First Amendment.  The Court of Appeals held that the statute applied to appellee and

column2: II
column3: III-B
column5: concluding that:

column1: 1. Appellee's publication and distribution of the ""Special Edition"" violated  316.  Pp.  479 U. S. 245-251.

(a) There is no merit to appellee's contention that preparation and distribution of the ""Special Edition"" does not fall within  316's definition of ""expenditure"" as the provision of various things of value ""to any candidate
column2: campaign committee
column3: or political party or organization
column5: especially since the general definitions section of the FECA broadly defines ""expenditure"" as including provision of anything of value made ""for the purpose of influencing any election for Federal office.""  Moreover
column6: the legislative history clearly confirms that  316 was meant to proscribe expenditures in connection with an election.  That history makes clear that Congress has long regarded it as insufficient merely to restrict payments made directly to candidates or campaign organizations.  Pp.  479 U. S. 245-248.

column1: (b) An expenditure must constitute ""express advocacy"" in order to be subject to  316's prohibition.  Here
column2: the publication of the ""Special Edition"" constituted ""express advocacy
column3: since it represented express advocacy of the election of particular candidates distributed to members of the general public.  Pp.  479 U. S. 248-250.

column1: (c) Appellee is not entitled to the press exemption under the FECA reserved for any news story
column2: commentary
column3: or editorial distributed through any ""periodical publication
column4: since even assuming that appellee's regular newsletter is exempt under this provision
column5: the ""Special Edition"" cannot be considered comparable to any single issue of the newsletter
column6: in view of the method by which it was prepared and distributed.  Pp.  479 U. S. 250-251.

column1: 2. Section 316's restriction of independent spending is unconstitutional as applied to appellee
column2: for it infringes protected speech without a compelling justification for such infringement.  The concern underlying the regulation of corporate political activity -- that organizations that amass great wealth in the economic marketplace not gain unfair advantage in the political marketplace -- is absent with regard to appellee.  Appellee was formed to disseminate political ideas
column3: not to amass capital.  It has no shareholders or other persons having a claim on its assets or earnings
column4: but obtains its funds from persons who make contributions to further the organization's political purposes.  It was not established by a business corporation or a labor union
column5: and its policy is not to accept contributions from such entities.  Pp.  479 U. S. 256-265.

column2: joined by JUSTICE MARSHALL
column3: JUSTICE POWELL
column5: concluded in Part III-A that the practical effect of applying  316 to appellee of discouraging protected speech is sufficient to characterize  316 as an infringement on First Amendment activities.  As a corporation
column6: appellee is subject to more extensive requirements and more stringent restrictions under the FECA than it would be if was not incorporated.  These include detailed recordkeeping and disclosure obligations
column7: the requirement of a complex and formalized organization
column8: and a limitation on whom can be solicited for contributions
column9: all of which create a disincentive for such an organization to engage in political speech.  Pp.  479 U. S. 251-256.

column2: agreeing that  316 is unconstitutional as applied to appellee's conduct at issue
column3: concluded that the significant burden on appellee comes not from the statute's disclosure requirements that appellee must satisfy
column4: but from the additional organizational restraints imposed upon it by the statute.  These restraints do not further the Government's informational interest in campaign disclosure
column5: and cannot be justified by any of the other interests identified by the FEC.  Pp.  479 U. S. 265-266.

column1: Respondent approached a Denver police officer and stated that he had murdered someone and wanted to talk about it.  The officer advised respondent of his Miranda rights
column2: and respondent said that he understood those rights
column3: but still wanted to talk about the murder.  Shortly thereafter
column4: a detective arrived and again advised respondent of his rights.  After respondent answered that he had come all the way from Boston to confess to the murder
column5: he was taken to police headquarters.  He then openly detailed his story to the police and subsequently pointed out the exact location of the murder.  He was held overnight
column6: and the next day he became visibly disoriented during an interview with the public defender's office and was sent to a state hospital for evaluation.  Interviews with a psychiatrist revealed that respondent was following the ""voice of God"" in confessing to the murder.  On the basis of the psychiatrist's testimony that respondent suffered from a psychosis that interfered with his ability to make free and rational choices and
column7: although not preventing him from understanding his rights
column8: motivated his confession
column9: the trial court suppressed respondent's initial statements and custodial confession because they were ""involuntary
column10: notwithstanding the fact that the police had done nothing wrong or coercive in securing the confession.  The court also found that respondent's mental state vitiated his attempted waiver of the right to counsel and the privilege against self-incrimination.  The Colorado Supreme Court affirmed
column11: holding that the Federal Constitution requires a court to suppress a confession when the defendant's mental state
column13: interfered with his ""rational intellect"" and his ""free will
column14: the very admission of the evidence in a court of law being sufficient state action to implicate the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.  The court further held that respondent's mental condition precluded his ability to make a valid waiver of his Miranda rights
column15: and that the State had not met its burden of proving a waiver by ""clear and convincing evidence.""

column1: 1. Coercive police activity is a necessary predicate to finding that a confession is not ""voluntary"" within the meaning of the Due Process Clause.  Here
column2: the taking of respondent's statements and their admission into evidence constituted no violation of that Clause.  While a defendant's mental condition may be a ""significant"" factor in the ""voluntariness""
this does not justify a conclusion that his mental condition
column3: by itself and apart from its relation to official coercion
column4: should ever dispose of the inquiry into constitutional ""voluntariness.""  Pp.  479 U. S. 163-167.

column1: 2. Whenever the State bears the burden of proof in a motion to suppress a statement allegedly obtained in violation of the Miranda doctrine
column2: the State need prove waiver only by a preponderance of the evidence.  Lego v. Twomey
column5: reaffirmed.  Thus
column6: the Colorado Supreme Court erred in applying a ""clear and convincing evidence"" standard.  That court also erred in its analysis of the question whether respondent had waived his Miranda rights.  Notions of ""free will"" have no place in this area of constitutional law.  Respondent's perception of coercion flowing from the ""voice of God"" is a matter to which the Federal Constitution does not speak.  Pp.  479 U. S. 167-171.

column2: reversed and remanded.

column1: A Washington statute ( 29.18.110) requires that a minor party candidate for office receive at least 1% of all votes cast for that office in the State's primary election before the candidate's name will be placed on the general election ballot.  Appellee Peoples qualified to be placed on the primary election ballot as the nominee of appellee Socialist Workers Party (Party) for United States Senator.  At the primary
column2: he received less than 1% of the total votes cast for the office
column3: and
column5: his name was not placed on the general election ballot.  Peoples
column6: the Party
column7: and appellee registered voters then brought an action in Federal District Court
column8: alleging that  29.18.110 violated their rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments.  The District Court denied relief
column9: but the Court of Appeals reversed
column11: as applied to candidates for statewide offices

column1: Held:  Section 29.18.110 is constitutional.  Pp.  479 U. S. 193-199.
(a) States have a right to require candidates to make a preliminary showing of substantial support in order to qualify for a place on the ballot.  Jenness v. Fortson
column2: 403 U. S. 431; American Party of Texas v. White

column1: (b) The fact that Washington's political history evidences no voter confusion from ballot overcrowding does not require invalidation of  29.18.110.   A State is not required to prove actual voter confusion
column2: ballot overcrowding
column3: or the presence of frivolous candidates as a predicate to imposing reasonable ballot access restrictions.  In any event
column4: the record in this case discloses that enactment of  29.18.110 was
column5: in fact
column6: linked to the legislature's perception that the general election ballot was becoming cluttered with minor party candidates who did not command significant voter support
column7: and the State was clearly entitled to raise the ante for ballot access
column8: to simplify the general election ballot
column9: and to avoid the possibility of unrestrained factionalism at the general election.  Pp.  479 U. S. 194-196.

column1: (c) The burdens imposed on appellees' First Amendment rights by  29.18.110 are not too severe to be justified by the State's interest in restricting access to the general ballot.  Pp.  479 U. S. 196-197.

(d) The differences between requiring primary votes to qualify for a position on the general election ballot and requiring signatures on nominating petitions are not of constitutional dimension.  Pp.  479 U. S. 197-198.
(e) There is no merit to appellees' argument that
column2: since voter turnout at primary elections is generally lower than the turnout at general elections
column3: 29.18.110 has reduced the pool of potential supporters from which appellee Party candidates can secure 1% of the vote.  The statute creates no impediment to voting at primary elections
column4: and does no more than require a candidate to show a ""significant modicum"" of voter support in primary elections.  P.  479 U. S. 198.

column1: (f) Section 29.18.110 serves to promote the very First Amendment values that are threatened by overly burdensome ballot access restrictions.  Washington's voters are not denied freedom of association because they must channel their expressive activity into a campaign at the primary as opposed to the general election.  Pp.  479 U. S. 198-199.

Appellee Peoples qualified to be placed on the primary election ballot as the nominee of appellee Socialist Workers Party (Party) for United States Senator.  At the primary
column2: he received less than 1% of the total votes cast for the office
column3: and
column5: his name was not placed on the general election ballot.  Peoples
column6: the Party
column7: and appellee registered voters then brought an action in Federal District Court
column8: alleging that  29.18.110 violated their rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments.  The District Court denied relief
column9: but the Court of Appeals reversed
column11: as applied to candidates for statewide offices

column1: Held:  Section 29.18.110 is constitutional.  Pp.  479 U. S. 193-199.
(a) States have a right to require candidates to make a preliminary showing of substantial support in order to qualify for a place on the ballot.  Jenness v. Fortson
column2: 403 U. S. 431; American Party of Texas v. White

column1: (b) The fact that Washington's political history evidences no voter confusion from ballot overcrowding does not require invalidation of  29.18.110.   A State is not required to prove actual voter confusion
column2: ballot overcrowding
column3: or the presence of frivolous candidates as a predicate to imposing reasonable ballot access restrictions.  In any event
column4: the record in this case discloses that enactment of  29.18.110 was
column5: in fact
column6: linked to the legislature's perception that the general election ballot was becoming cluttered with minor party candidates who did not command significant voter support
column7: and the State was clearly entitled to raise the ante for ballot access
column8: to simplify the general election ballot
column9: and to avoid the possibility of unrestrained factionalism at the general election.  Pp.  479 U. S. 194-196.

column1: (c) The burdens imposed on appellees' First Amendment rights by  29.18.110 are not too severe to be justified by the State's interest in restricting access to the general ballot.  Pp.  479 U. S. 196-197.

(d) The differences between requiring primary votes to qualify for a position on the general election ballot and requiring signatures on nominating petitions are not of constitutional dimension.  Pp.  479 U. S. 197-198.
(e) There is no merit to appellees' argument that
column2: since voter turnout at primary elections is generally lower than the turnout at general elections
column3: 29.18.110 has reduced the pool of potential supporters from which appellee Party candidates can secure 1% of the vote.  The statute creates no impediment to voting at primary elections
column4: and does no more than require a candidate to show a ""significant modicum"" of voter support in primary elections.  P.  479 U. S. 198.

column1: (f) Section 29.18.110 serves to promote the very First Amendment values that are threatened by overly burdensome ballot access restrictions. enacted in 1956
column3: requires voters in any political party primary to be registered members of that party.  In 1984
column4: appellee Republican Party of Connecticut (Party) adopted a Party rule that permits independent voters -- registered voters not affiliated with any party -- to vote in Republican primaries for federal and statewide offices.  The Party and the Party's federal officeholders and state chairman (also appellees) brought an action in Federal District Court challenging the constitutionality of  9-431 on the ground that it deprives the Party of its right under the First and Fourteenth Amendments to enter into political association with individuals of its own choosing
column5: and seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.  The District Court granted summary judgment in appellees' favor
column6: and the Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: 1. Section 9-431 impermissibly burdens the rights of the Party and its members protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments.  Pp.  479 U. S. 213-225.

(a) The freedom of association protected by those Amendments includes partisan political organization.  Section 9-431 places limits upon the group of registered voters whom the Party may invite to participate in the ""basic function"" of selecting the Party's candidates.  The State thus limits the Party's associational opportunities at the crucial juncture at which the appeal to common principles may be translated into concerted action
column2: and hence to political power in the community.  The fact that the State has the power to regulate the time
column3: place
column4: and manner of elections does not justify
column5: without more
column6: the abridgment of fundamental rights
column7: such as the right to vote or
column8: as here
column9: the freedom of political association.  Pp.  479 U. S. 213-217.

column1: (b) The interests asserted by appellant Secretary of State of Connecticut as justification for the statute -- that it ensures the administrability of the primary
column2: prevents voter raiding
column3: avoids voter confusion
column4: and protects the integrity of the two-party system and the responsibility

column1: of party government -- are insubstantial.  The possibility of increases in the cost of administering the election system is not a sufficient basis for infringing appellees' First Amendment rights.  The interest in curtailing raiding is not implicated
column2: since  9-431 does not impede a raid on the Republican Party by independent voters; independent raiders need only register as Republicans and vote in the primary.  The interest in preventing voter confusion does not make it necessary to burden the Party's associational rights.  And even if the State were correct in arguing that  9-431
column3: in providing for a closed primary system
column4: is designed to save the Party from undertaking conduct destructive of its own interests
column5: the State may not constitutionally substitute its judgment for that of the Party
column6: whose determination of the boundaries of its own association and of the structure that best allows it to pursue its political goals is protected by the Constitution.  Pp.  479 U. S. 217-225.

column1: 2. The implementation of the Party rule will not violate the Qualifications Clause of the Constitution -- which provides that the House of Representatives ""shall be composed of Members chosen . . . by the People of the several States
column2: and the Electors in each State shall have the Qualifications requisite for Electors of the most numerous Branch of the State Legislature"" -- and the parallel provision of the Seventeenth Amendment
column3: because it does not disenfranchise any voter in a federal election who was qualified to vote in a primary or general election for the more numerous house of the state legislature.  The Clause and the Amendment are not violated by the fact that the Party rule establishes qualifications for voting in congressional elections that differ from the qualifications in elections for the state legislature.  Where state law
column5: has made the primary an integral part of the election procedure
column6: the requirements of the Clause and the Amendment apply to primaries as well as to general elections.  The achievement of the goal of the Clause to prevent the mischief that would arise if state voters found themselves disqualified from participating in federal elections does not require that qualifications for exercise of the federal franchise be precisely equivalent to the qualifications for exercising the franchise in a given State.  Pp.  479 U. S. 225-229.

column1: Section 16 of the Clayton Act entitles a private party to sue for injunctive relief against ""threatened loss or damage by a violation of the antitrust laws.""  Respondent
column2: the country's fifth-largest beef packer
column3: brought an action in Federal District Court under  16 to enjoin the proposed merger of petitioner Excel Corporation
column5: and Spencer Beef
column6: the third-largest packer.  Respondent alleged that it was threatened with a loss of profits by the possibility that Excel
column7: after the merger
column8: would lower its prices to a level at or above its costs in an attempt to increase its market share.  During trial
column9: Excel moved for dismissal on the ground that respondent had failed to allege or show that it would suffer antitrust injury
column10: but the District Court denied the motion.  After trial
column11: the District Court held that respondent's allegation of a ""price-cost squeeze"" that would severely narrow its profit margins constituted an allegation of antitrust injury.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column12: holding that respondent's allegation of a ""price-cost squeeze"" was not simply one of injury from competition
column13: but was a claim of injury by a form of predatory pricing in which Excel would drive other companies out of the market.

column1: 1. A private plaintiff seeking injunctive relief under  16 must show a threat of injury ""of the type the antitrust laws were designed to prevent and that flows from that which makes defendants' acts unlawful.""  Brunswick Corp. v. Pueblo Bowl-O-Mat
column2: Inc.

column1: 2. The proposed merger does not constitute a threat of antitrust injury.  A showing
column2: as in this case
column3: of loss or damage due merely to increased competition does not constitute such injury.  And while predatory pricing is capable of inflicting antitrust injury
column4: here respondent neither raised nor proved any claim of predatory pricing before the District Court
column5: and thus the Court of Appeals erred in interpreting respondent's allegations as equivalent to allegations of injury from predatory conduct.  Pp.  479 U. S. 113-119.

column2: however
column3: will not adopt in effect a per se rule denying competitors standing to challenge acquisitions on the basis of predatory

column1: pricing theories.  Nothing in the Clayton Act's language or legislative history suggests that Congress intended this Court to ignore injuries caused by such anticompetitive practices as predatory pricing.  Pp.  479 U. S. 120-122.

a New Jersey corporation with its principal office and only manufacturing facilities located in North Carolina
column3: blends tobacco imported from foreign countries with domestic tobacco in producing finished tobacco products virtually all of which are consumed in the United States.  Upon importation
column4: the foreign tobacco is placed under customs bond given by appellant
column5: and is stored in one or more of the customs-bonded warehouses owned and maintained by appellant in appellee Forsyth and Durham Counties
column6: N. C.
column7: usually for a 2-year period to permit aging.  Appellant pays the required customs duties upon withdrawal of the tobacco from the warehouses.  Under North Carolina statutes
column8: tobacco present in the State on January 1 of each year is subject to a nondiscriminatory ad valorem property tax levied and collected by counties and municipalities.  In listing its taxable personal property for 1983 in appellee counties
column10: under the ruling in Xerox Corp. v. County of Harris
column12: its imported tobacco in customs-bonded warehouses was immune from state taxation on federal constitutional grounds.  The counties' tax supervisors denied the claim
column13: and the denials were upheld on administrative appeals.  The North Carolina Court of Appeals affirmed
column14: rejecting appellant's contentions that the tax violated the Import-Export and Due Process Clauses
column16: reasoning that it prohibited state taxation only of imported goods stored under bond and awaiting export
column17: not of those destined for domestic manufacture and consumption.  Appellant filed with the North Carolina Supreme Court both a notice of appeal and a petition for discretionary review.  The court granted a motion to dismiss for lack of a substantial constitutional question and denied appellant's petition.  Appellant then filed with this Court an appeal from the North Carolina Supreme Court and another appeal from the North Carolina Court of Appeals.

column3: and the decision is in favor of its validity.  Pp.  479 U. S. 136-139.""

column2: and there was a final judgment in favor of validity.  Cf. Japan Line
column3: Ltd. v. County of Los Angeles

column1: (b) The appeal from the North Carolina Supreme Court
column2: not the North Carolina Court of Appeals
column3: is the proper one under  1257(2).  A North Carolina statute gives a litigant an appeal of right to the State Supreme Court from any Court of Appeals decision that ""directly involves a substantial question arising under the Constitution of the United States.""  In the absence of positive assurance to the contrary by the North Carolina Supreme Court
column4: its grant of appellees' motion to dismiss the appeal for lack of a substantial federal constitutional question constitutes a decision on the merits affirming the Court of Appeals' judgment
column5: not a determination that the State Supreme Court lacked jurisdiction over the appeal.  Pp.  479 U. S. 138-139.

column2: a State may impose a nondiscriminatory ad valorem property tax on imported goods stored in a customs-bonded warehouse and destined for domestic manufacture and sale.  The holding in Xerox Corp. v. County of Harris
column3: supra
column4: is limited to its factual situation
column5: that is
column6: where taxed imported goods in customs-bonded warehouses are intended for transshipment in foreign commerce.  North Carolina's taxation of appellant's goods does not contradict the purposes of the federal statutory scheme governing customs-bonded warehouses to promote foreign commerce and to aid certain sectors of American economic life.  To invalidate the North Carolina tax would place domestic tobacco
column7: which is subject to the ad valorem property tax while aging
column8: at a distinct disadvantage to the imported tobacco; domestic producers and local taxpayers would ""subsidize"" the growers of imported tobacco.  Nor does the taxation here conflict with the central purpose behind customs-bonded warehouses:  to ensure that federal customs duties are collected. The federal statutes and regulations that guide monitoring the movement of imported goods and the warehouse proprietor's conduct with respect to such goods both guarantee the collection of federal revenues and are not so comprehensive as to leave no room for North Carolina's assessment of ad valorem taxes. column1: 3. Application of the North Carolina tax to appellant's imported tobacco does not violate the Import-Export Clause.  The focus of Import-Export Clause cases is on the nature of the tax at issue

column3: and benefits given by the State.  In light of the police
column5: and other services provided to appellant's imported tobacco by North Carolina counties and cities
column6: such a ""fiscal relation"" clearly exists in this case.  P.  479 U. S. 156.

column1: The United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit held below that petitioner's Sixth Amendment right to the assistance of counsel was not violated when he was refused counsel at his preliminary hearing on a capital murder charge
column2: because the denial of counsel at the preliminary hearing was harmless error.

column1: Petitioner Donald Wayne Thomas was convicted of murder and sentenced to death after jury trial. The State of Georgia charged petitioner
column2: who was then nineteen years old
column3: with the murder of a nine-year-old boy. At the preliminary hearing held ten days after petitioner's arrest
column4: petitioner requested an opportunity to retain private counsel
column5: indicating that he did not wish to be represented by the public defender. The court denied petitioner's request
column6: excused the public defender
column7: and held the preliminary hearing in the absence of any defense counsel. The State's main witness
column8: a fifteen-year-old mentally retarded girl
column9: then testified without cross-examination that petitioner had told her he had committed the murder
column10: and had shown her the body. This testimony differed in various material respects from the later testimony given by this witness at trial.

column1: On direct appeal from petitioner's subsequent conviction
column2: the Georgia Supreme Court affirmed the conviction and sentence. Thomas v. State
column5: vacated the sentence of death
column6: and remanded for reconsideration in light of Godfrey v. Georgia
column7: 446 U.S. 420 (1980). Thomas v. Georgia
column8: 449 U.S. 988 (1980). On remand
column9: the Georgia Supreme Court reinstated the death sentence
column10: without benefit of further briefing or oral argument. Thomas v. State
column14: 452 U.S. 973d 984 (1981). Having exhausted in state post-conviction proceedings claims of ineffective assistance of counsel and prosecutorial misconduct at the sentencing phase of the trial
column15: petitioner's counsel brought a federal habeas corpus action raising those issues.

column1: During the pendency of the federal petition
column2: counsel

column1: 1. This case presents no issue that requires

S. 68-69.
3. Because both of the courts below applied an erroneous view of the law
column2: neither explicitly considered the question whether the Board's leave policy constituted a reasonable accommodation of respondent's religious beliefs. column3: the District Court should make the necessary findings as to past and existing practice in the administration of the collective bargaining agreements.  Pp.  479 U. S. 70-71.

column1: liquor for consumption on the premises.  Respondents

column1: This case concerns an application of the ""separate document"" requirement for judgments contained in Rule 58 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. [Footnote 1] I dissent from the denial of certiorari because I am persuaded that the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit misconstrued our prior cases having to do with the requirement. [ Amoco Oil Co. v. Jim Heilig Oil & Gas
Petitioner Amoco Oil Co. took an appeal from an order issued by the Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of Michigan. On May 21
column3: the District Court affirmed the Bankruptcy Court's ruling by a memorandum and order consisting of a single document. Petitioner moved for reconsideration. The motion was denied on June 28 in a similar single- document memorandum and order. [Footnote 2]
Amoco filed a notice of appeal with the Court of Appeals for the Sixty Circuit. That court issued an order directing Amoco to show cause why the appeal should not be dismissed. It suggested that
column4: because the District Court had issued

column1: its initial memorandum opinion and order on May 21
column2: Amoco's filing would be 35 days late under Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure 4(a) and 26(a). App. to Pet. for Cert. C-1. In response
column3: Amoco contended that
column5: its appeal actually was premature
column6: given that the District Court had never entered a judgment separate from the May 21 memorandum and order as Rule 58 requires. The Court of Appeals rejected this contention. It observed that in Bankers Trust Co. v. Mallis
column7: 435 U.S. 381 (1978) (per curiam)
column8: this Court had adopted a common-sense
column10: approach to the requirements of Rule 58 so long as no party was misled. App. to Pet. for Cert. D-1. The Court of Appeals further noted that Amoco's motion for reconsideration of the May 21 memorandum and order demonstrated that Amoco considered that opinion to be the final decision. Accordingly
column12: ""The mere technicality that the district court failed to file a separate judgment should not be used to give jurisdiction to this Court of an untimely filed appeal in which the parties were not misled by the lack of a separate judgment."" App. to Pet. for Cert. D-1 to D-2.

column1: Rule 58 provides in pertinent part: ""Every judgment shall be set forth on a separate document."" See n. 1
column2: supra. The genesis and purpose of this ""separate document"" requirement
column3: which was added to Rule 58 by amendment in 1963
column4: are explained in the Advisory Committee Notes. Prior to the amendment difficulties had arisen in situations where a court had "" written an opinion or memorandum containing some apparently directive or dispositive words
column5: e.g.
column6: 'the plaintiff's motion [for summary judgment] is granted.' "" 28 U.S.C.App.
column7: p. 627. At times court clerks had viewed these documents as a sufficient basis for entering a judgment. Problems occasionally arose
column8: however
column9: when the documents did not provide all the necessary elements of the judgment or when the court later would issue a formal judgment. Parties were thus uncertain as to when the judgment was effective and as to when the time began to run for purposes of filing post- judgment motions and appeals. The Advisory Committee observed: ""The amended rule eliminates these uncertainties by requiring that there be a judgment set out on a separate document-distinct from any opinion or memorandum-which provides the basis for the entry of judgment."" Id.

column1: widely accepted judicial exception to discharge for criminal sentences

column1: Section 1 of Article XV of the Agreement in Implementation of Article III of the Panama Canal Treaty provides that the Panama Canal Commission and its contractors ""are exempt from payment in the Republic of Panama of all taxes . . . on their activities or property.""  The first sentence of  2 of Article XV provides that ""United States citizen employees . . . shall be exempt from any taxes . . . on income received as a result of their work for the Commission
column2: and the second sentence exempts such employees ""from payment of taxes . . . on income derived from sources outside the Republic of Panama.""  Section 3 provides that such employees

column1: shall be exempt from taxes . . . on gifts or inheritance or on personal property
column2: the presence of which within the territory of the Republic of Panama is due solely to the stay therein of such persons on account of their . . . work with the Commission.""
United States citizen employees of the Panama Canal Commission and their spouses
column3: sought refunds of United States income taxes collected on salaries paid by the Commission for certain years
column4: contending that  2 of Article XV constitutes an express exemption of those salaries from both Panamanian and United States taxation.  The Claims Court agreed
column5: but the Court of Appeals reversed.

column1: Held:  Article XV applies only to Panamanian taxes
column2: and hence petitioners are not entitled to refunds of United States income taxes paid.  Section 1 of Article XV establishes the context for the discussion of tax exemption in the entire Article
column3: so that when  2 and 3 state that ""United States citizen employees . . . shall be exempt"" from taxes they are understood to be dealing only with taxes payable in Panama.  If the first sentence of  2 were interpreted to refer to United States as well as Panamanian taxes
column4: then the second sentence and  3 would also do so
column5: with the implausible consequence that United States citizen employees would be exempt not only from United States income taxes on their earnings from the Commission but also from such taxes on income from sources outside Panama and from all United States gift and inheritance taxes.

column2: affirmed.
J.
column3: delivered the opinion for a unanimous Court.

column1: After an Arkansas State Trooper was killed in the line of duty
column2: his widow (petitioner) received a $50
column3: 000 benefit from the Federal Government pursuant to the Public Safety Officers' Death Benefits Act.  The Act provides that its benefits ""shall be in addition to any other benefit that may be due from any other source
column4: with certain exceptions not applicable here.  Petitioner also applied for death benefits under the Arkansas Workers' Compensation Act
column5: which contains a provision (enacted three years after the federal Benefits Act) stating that benefits under the State Act shall be reduced by the amount of any federal payment under ""an Act of Congress providing benefits for public safety officers.""  State administrative proceedings instituted by petitioner ultimately resulted in the rejection of her claim that her state benefits should not be offset by the federal payment.  It was held that there was no inconsistency between the state and federal laws
column6: and thus that the state statute need not give way under the Supremacy Clause of the Federal Constitution.  The Arkansas Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  The Arkansas statute authorizes the precise conduct that Congress sought to prohibit
column2: and consequently is repugnant to the Supremacy Clause.  The conflict between the Arkansas law and the federal Benefits Act is clear from the language of the statutes.  The state court's reasoning that the federal law did not alter the States' traditional right to set the level of workers' compensation benefits misses the point.  The Benefits Act does not require a State to set a particular benefit level for its

column1: citizens; it simply prohibits a State from reducing the compensation it otherwise would provide to account for the federal payment.  This reading of the Benefits Act is consistent with the legislative history
column2: that shows that Congress was concerned about the inadequacy of death benefits paid to police officers by some States.  Richardson v. Belcher

column1: After an Arkansas State Trooper was killed in the line of duty
column2: his widow (petitioner) received a $50
column3: 000 benefit from the Federal Government pursuant to the Public Safety Officers' Death Benefits Act.  The Act provides that its benefits ""shall be in addition to any other benefit that may be due from any other source
column4: with certain exceptions not applicable here.  Petitioner also applied for death benefits under the Arkansas Workers' Compensation Act
column5: which contains a provision (enacted three years after the federal Benefits Act) stating that benefits under the State Act shall be reduced by the amount of any federal payment under ""an Act of Congress providing benefits for public safety officers.""  State administrative proceedings instituted by petitioner ultimately resulted in the rejection of her claim that her state benefits should not be offset by the federal payment.  It was held that there was no inconsistency between the state and federal laws
column6: and thus that the state statute need not give way under the Supremacy Clause of the Federal Constitution.  The Arkansas Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  The Arkansas statute authorizes the precise conduct that Congress sought to prohibit
column2: and consequently is repugnant to the Supremacy Clause.  The conflict between the Arkansas law and the federal Benefits Act is clear from the language of the statutes.  The state court's reasoning that the federal law did not alter the States' traditional right to set the level of workers' compensation benefits misses the point.  The Benefits Act does not require a State to set a particular benefit level for its

column1: citizens; it simply prohibits a State from reducing the compensation it otherwise would provide to account for the federal payment.  This reading of the Benefits Act is consistent with the legislative history
column2: that shows that Congress was concerned about the inadequacy of death benefits paid to police officers by some States.  Richardson v. Belcher

column3: reversed and remanded."|

column1: An application by a daughter and son-in-law of former President Marcos of the Philippines to stay the District Court's contempt order
column2: requiring their incarceration if they failed to testify on July 22
column4: before a federal grand jury investigating alleged corruption relating to arms contracts made with the Philippine Government
column5: is granted
column6: conditioned upon applicants' filing a petition for certiorari by August 5
column7: 1986.  Applicants contended that requiring them to testify would violate their Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination because their testimony might be used against them in related criminal proceedings currently pending in the Philippines.  The District Court granted the United States' motion to give applicants use and derivative use immunity as to criminal prosecutions in the United States
column8: and also entered a restrictive order to protect the secrecy of their testimony
column9: holding that the constitutional question was not presented because they had not demonstrated a real and substantial danger of prosecution abroad.  The Court of Appeals affirmed on different grounds
column10: finding that applicants faced a substantial possibility of prosecution in the Philippines; that the District Court's restrictive order was insufficient to protect against disclosures to the Philippine Government; that therefore the constitutional question was presented; and that the Fifth Amendment privilege was not violated simply because compelled testimony might be used in a foreign prosecution.  The application for a stay is granted because (1) there is a reasonable probability that four Justices will vote to grant certiorari to consider the issue whether the Fifth Amendment privilege protects a witness from being compelled to give testimony that may later be used against him in a foreign prosecution; (2) there is a fair prospect that a majority of the Justices will decide the issue in applicants' favor; and (3) a balancing of the equities weighs in applicants' favor.

column1: A New York statute authorizes closure of a building found to be a public health nuisance because it was being used as a place for prostitution and lewdness.  After a county Deputy Sheriff's undercover investigation of respondents' ""adult"" bookstore disclosed that illicit sexual activities
column2: including solicitation of prostitution
column3: occurred on the premises
column4: a civil complaint was filed against respondents seeking closure of the premises under the statute.  Respondents answered by alleging
column5: inter alia
column6: that a closure would impermissibly interfere with their First Amendment right to sell books on the premises
column7: and that the closure statute was not intended to apply to establishments other than houses of prostitution.  The New York trial court denied respondents' motion for a summary judgment
column8: holding that the statute applied to respondents.  The Appellate Division affirmed.  The New York Court of Appeals reversed on First Amendment grounds.  Applying the test of United States v. O'Brien
column10: for determining the validity of a statute regulating conduct that has an expressive element
column11: the court held that the closure statute failed the part of the O'Brien test that requires the statute to be no broader than necessary to achieve its purpose
column12: because the closure order was much broader than necessary to achieve the restriction against illicit sexual activities and because an injunction against continuing those activities could achieve the same effect without restricting respondents' bookselling activities.

column1: Held:  The First Amendment does not bar enforcement of the closure statute against respondents' bookstore.  United States v. O'Brien
column2: supra
column3: has no relevance to a statute directed at imposing sanctions on nonexpressive activity
column4: and the sexual activities carried on in this case manifest absolutely no element of protected expression.  The closure statute is directed at unlawful conduct having nothing to do with books or other expressive activity.  Bookselling on premises used for prostitution does not confer First Amendment coverage to defeat a statute aimed at penalizing and terminating illegal uses of premises.  Pp.  478 U. S. 702-707.

column1: In order to eliminate the federal budget deficit
column2: Congress enacted the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 (Act)
column3: popularly known as the ""Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act
column4: which sets a maximum deficit amount for federal spending for each of the fiscal years 1986 through 1991 (progressively reducing the deficit amount to zero in 1991).  If in any fiscal year the budget deficit exceeds the prescribed maximum by more than a specified sum
column5: the Act requires basically across-the-board cuts in federal spending to reach the targeted deficit level.  These reductions are accomplished under the ""reporting provisions"" spelled out in  251 of the Act
column6: which requires the Directors of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) to submit their deficit estimates and program-by-program budget reduction calculations to the Comptroller General
column7: who
column8: after reviewing the Directors' joint report
column9: then reports his conclusions to the President.  The President in turn must issue a ""sequestration"" order mandating the spending reductions specified by the Comptroller General
column10: and the sequestration order becomes effective unless
column12: Congress legislates reductions to obviate the need for the sequestration order.  The Act also contains in  274(f) a ""fallback"" deficit reduction process (eliminating the Comptroller General's participation) to take effect if  251's reporting provisions are invalidated.  In consolidated actions in the Federal District Court
column13: individual Congressmen and the National Treasury Employees Union (Union) (who
column14: along with one of the Union's members
column15: are appellees here) challenged the Act's constitutionality.  The court held
column17: that the Comptroller General's role in exercising executive functions under the Act's deficit reduction process violated the constitutionally imposed doctrine of separation of powers because the Comptroller General is removable only by a congressional

column2: and Congress may not retain the power of removal over an officer performing executive powers.

column1: 1. The fact that members of the Union
column2: one of whom is an appellee here
column3: will sustain injury because the Act suspends certain scheduled cost-of-living benefit increases to the members
column4: is sufficient to create standing under a provision of the Act and Article III to challenge the Act's constitutionality.  Therefore
column5: the standing issue as to the Union itself or Members of Congress need not be considered.  P.  478 U. S. 721.

column1: 2. The powers vested in the Comptroller General under  251 violate the Constitution's command that Congress play no direct role in the execution of the laws.  Pp.  478 U. S. 721-734.
(a) Under the constitutional principle of separation of powers
column2: Congress cannot reserve for itself the power of removal of an officer charged with the execution of the laws except by impeachment.  To permit the execution of the laws to be vested in an officer answerable only to Congress would
column3: in practical terms
column4: reserve in Congress control of the execution of the laws.  The structure of the Constitution does not permit Congress to execute the laws; it follows that Congress cannot grant to an officer under its control what it does not possess.  Cf. INS v Chadha

column1: (b) There is no merit to the contention that the Comptroller General performs his duties independently and is not subservient to Congress.  Although nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate
column2: the Comptroller General is removable only at the initiative of Congress.  Under controlling statutes
column3: he may be removed not only by impeachment but also by joint resolution of Congress ""at any time"" for specified causes
column5: ""neglect of duty
column6: and ""malfeasance.""  The quoted terms
column7: as interpreted by Congress
column8: could sustain removal of a Comptroller General for any number of actual or perceived transgressions of the legislative will.  Moreover
column9: the political realities do not reveal that the Comptroller General is free from Congress' influence.  He heads the General Accounting Office
column12: is ""an instrumentality of the United States Government independent of the executive departments
column13: and Congress has consistently viewed the Comptroller General as an officer of the Legislative Branch.  Over the years
column14: the Comptrollers General have also viewed themselves as part of the Legislative Branch.  Thus
column15: because Congress has retained removal authority over the Comptroller General
column16: he may not be entrusted with executive powers.  Pp.  478 U. S. 727-732.

column2: the Comptroller General has been improperly assigned executive powers.  Although he is to have ""due regard"" for the estimates and reductions contained in the joint report of

column4: the Comptroller General will exercise his independent judgment and evaluation with respect to those estimates
column5: and will make decisions of the kind that are made by officers charged with executing a statute.  The Act's provisions give him
column6: not the President
column7: the ultimate authority in determining what budget cuts are to be made.  By placing the responsibility for execution of the Act in the hands of an officer who is subject to removal only by itself

column11: and has unconstitutionally intruded into the executive function.  Pp.  478 U. S. 732-734.

column1: This litigation arose from serious accidents that occurred in the reservoirs of federal flood control projects in Arkansas and Louisiana.  In both accidents
column2: recreational users (water-skiers in Arkansas and a fisherman in Louisiana) of the reservoirs were injured or drowned when they were swept through retaining structures after those structures were opened by the United States Corps of Engineers to control flooding.  Separate actions were brought in Federal District Court against the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act.  In the Arkansas case
column3: the court held that
column4: although Government agents had willfully and maliciously failed to warn of a known danger
column5: the Government was immune from damages under 33 U.S.C.  702c
column6: which provides in part that ""[n]o liability of any kind shall attach to or rest upon the United States for any damage from or by floods or flood waters at any place.""  In the Louisiana case
column7: the court similarly granted summary judgment for the United States despite the Government's concession that it negligently failed to warn of the danger from the current caused by open gates.  In a consolidated appeal
column8: the Court of Appeals reversed the judgments
column9: holding that Congress intended  702c to immunize the Government from liability for damage resulting directly from construction of flood control projects and for flooding caused by factors beyond the Government's control
column10: but had not intended to shield the negligent or wrongful acts of Government employees either in the construction or continued operation of flood control projects
column11: including the failure to warn the public of hazards to their use of reservoirs.

column1: Held:  Section 702c bars recovery against the Government in these cases.  Pp.  478 U. S. 604-612.

column2: 702c's language covers the accidents at issue.  The ordinary meaning of the word ""damage"" covers injury to both property and person
column3: and cannot be considered ambiguous in that it might refer only to damage to property.  Moreover
column4: the language ""any damage"" and ""liability of any kind"" undercuts a narrow construction.  Nor do the words ""flood"" and ""flood waters"" create any uncertainty in the context of these accidents.  Those words apply to all waters contained in or carried through a federal flood control project for purposes of or related to flood

column2: as well as to waters that such projects cannot control.  The waters here clearly fall within the statute's ambit.  Pp.  478 U. S. 604-605.

column1: (b) The statute's legislative history fully supports attributing to its unambiguous words their ordinary meaning.  Pp.  478 U. S. 606-608.

(c) There is little in the legislative history or otherwise to support the argument that  702c was meant to bar only claims against the Government for damage to property acquired under  702c's proviso (authorizing purchase of interests in certain properties bordering the Mississippi River) and under  702d (authorizing purchase of ""flowage rights"")
column2: and thus would allow recovery for damages to persons or property not connected with these acquisitions.  Nor is there any merit to the argument that
column3: even if  702c is intended to grant immunity in connection with flood control projects
column4: the Government is not entitled to immunity here because the injuries arose from Government employees' alleged mismanagement of recreational activities unrelated to flood control.  The manner in which to convey warnings
column5: including the negligent failure to do so
column6: is part of the ""management"" of a flood control project.  Finally
column7: the legislative history does not support construing  702c as immunizing the Government from liability only for property damage directly resulting from construction of flood control projects
column8: but rather indicates Congress' intention to protect the Government from any liability for damages that might arise out of flood control.  Pp.  478 U. S. 608-612.

column1: A Michigan statute makes an employee ineligible for unemployment compensation if he has provided ""financing
column2: by means other than the payment of regular union dues
column3: for a strike that causes his unemployment.  As authorized by their international union
column4: appellant employees of appellee General Motors Corp. (GM) were required to pay
column5: in addition to their regular union dues
column6: ""emergency dues"" to augment the union's strike insurance fund.  Although the union and GM reached an agreement on national issues at a time when negotiations for a collective bargaining agreement were taking place
column7: three local unions went on strike at GM foundries
column8: and strike fund benefits were paid to the striking employees from the fund in which emergency dues had been deposited.  As a result of the strikes
column9: operations were temporarily curtailed at other GM plants
column12: most of whom are appellants in this case.  Appellants' claims for unemployment benefits were ultimately denied by the Michigan Supreme Court on the ground that the emergency dues payments constituted ""financing"" of the strikes that caused appellants' unemployment
column13: thus making appellants ineligible for unemployment compensation under the Michigan statute. column5: appellants were exercising associational rights protected by  7 of the NLRA

column1: Petitioner was charged in an Illinois Circuit Court with committing the crimes of unlawful restraint and deviate sexual assault
column2: and the State filed a petition to have him declared a sexually dangerous person within the meaning of the Illinois Sexually Dangerous Persons Act (Act).  Pursuant to the Act
column3: the court ordered petitioner to submit to two psychiatric examinations.  At the bench trial on the petition
column4: the State presented the examining psychiatrists' testimony
column5: over petitioner's objection that they had elicited information from him in violation of his privilege against self-incrimination.  Based on that testimony
column6: as well as that of the victim of the sexual assault
column7: the court found petitioner to be a sexually dangerous person under the Act.  The Illinois Appellate Court reversed
column8: holding that the trial court had improperly relied on testimony in violation of petitioner's privilege against self-incrimination.  The Illinois Supreme Court reversed
column9: holding that that privilege was not available in sexually dangerous person proceedings because they are ""essentially civil in nature.""

column1: 1. Proceedings under the Act are not ""criminal"" within the meaning of the Fifth Amendment's guarantee against compulsory self-incrimination.  The Act's aim is to provide treatment
column2: not punishment
column3: for persons adjudged sexually dangerous.  That the State cannot file a sexually dangerous person petition under the Act unless it has already filed criminal charges against the person in question
column4: and thus has chosen not to apply the Act to the larger class of mentally ill persons who might be found sexually dangerous
column5: does not transform a civil proceeding into a criminal one.  The State must prove more than just the commission of a sexual assault.  It must prove the existence of a mental disorder for more than one year and a propensity to commit sexual assaults
column6: in addition to showing that propensity through sexual assault.  The fact that the Act provides some of the safeguards applicable in criminal proceedings -- rights to counsel
column7: to a jury trial
column8: and to confront and cross-examine witnesses
column9: and the requirement that sexual dangerousness be proved beyond a reasonable doubt -- cannot itself turn the proceedings under the Act into criminal proceedings requiring the full panoply of rights applicable there.  And the fact that a person adjudged sexually dangerous under the Act is committed to a maximum security institution that also

column1: houses convicts needing psychiatric care does not make the conditions of that person's confinement amount to ""punishment
column2: and thus render ""criminal"" the proceedings that led to confinement.  In re Gault

column1: 2. The Fourteenth Amendment's guarantee of due process does not require application of the Fifth Amendment's privilege against self-incrimination to proceedings under the Act.  That privilege is not designed to enhance the reliability of a factfinding determination
column2: but stands in the Constitution for entirely independent reasons.  Pp.  478 U. S. 374-375.

column1: The private petitioners -- who include employees of the North Carolina Agricultural Extension Service (Extension Service)
column2: recipients of its services
column3: members of its Homemaker Clubs
column4: and parents of youths that belong to its 4-H Clubs -- filed suit against various state and local officials in Federal District Court (the United States intervened as a plaintiff)
column5: alleging racial discrimination in employment and in provision of services by the Extension Service
column6: in violation of the Constitution and various federal statutes
column7: including Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.  The court refused to certify various proposed classes and entered judgment for respondents
column8: finding that petitioners had not carried their burden of demonstrating that respondents had engaged in a pattern or practice of racial discrimination.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: 1. For the reasons stated in the concurring opinion of JUSTICE BRENNAN
column2: the Court of Appeals erred:  in holding that
column3: under Title VII
column4: the Extension Service had no duty to eradicate salary disparities between white and black workers that had their origin prior to the date Title VII was made applicable to public employees; in disregarding petitioners' statistical analysis because it reflected pre-Title VII salary disparities; in holding that petitioners' regressions were unacceptable as evidence of discrimination; in ignoring evidence related to salary disparities presented by petitioners in addition to their multiple regression analyses; and in refusing to certify a class of black employees of the Extension Service
column5: although the Court of Appeals was correct in refusing to certify a class of defendant counties.

column1: 2. For the reasons stated in the opinion of JUSTICE WHITE
column2: neither the Constitution nor the applicable Department of Agriculture regulations required more than what the District Court and the Court of Appeals found the Extension Service has done to disestablish segregation in its 4-H and Homemaker Clubs.

column1: The Indiana Legislature consists of a 100-member House of Representatives and a 50-member Senate.  Representatives serve 2-year terms
column2: with elections for all seats every two years.  Senators serve 4-year terms
column3: with half of the seats up for election every two years.  Senators are elected from single-member districts
column4: while representatives are elected from a mixture of single-member and multimember districts.  In 1981
column5: the legislature reapportioned the districts pursuant to the 1980 census.  At that time
column6: there were Republican majorities in both the House and the Senate.  The reapportionment plan provided 50 single-member districts for the Senate and 7 triple-member
column7: 9 double-member
column8: and 61 single-member districts for the House.  The multimember districts generally included the State's metropolitan areas.  In 1982
column9: appellee Indiana Democrats filed suit in Federal District Court against appellant state officials
column10: alleging that the 1981 reapportionment plan constituted a political gerrymander intended to disadvantage Democrats
column11: and that the particular district lines that were drawn and the mix of single-member and multimember districts were intended to and did violate their right
column13: to equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.  In November 1982
column14: before the case went to trial
column15: elections were held under the new plan.  Democratic candidates for the House received 51.9% of votes cast statewide
column16: but only 43 out of the 100 seats to be filled.  Democratic candidates for the Senate received 53.1% of the votes cast statewide
column17: and 13 out of the 25 Democratic candidates were elected.  In Marion and Allen Counties
column18: both divided into multimember House districts
column19: Democratic candidates drew 46.6% of the vote
column20: but only 3 of the 21 Democratic candidates were elected.  Subsequently
column21: relying primarily on the 1982 election results as proof of unconstitutionally discriminatory vote dilution
column22: the District Court invalidated the 1981 reapportionment plan
column23: enjoined appellants from holding elections pursuant thereto
column24: and ordered the legislature to prepare a new plan.

column2: reversed.

column1: (a) A threshold showing of discriminatory vote dilution is required for a prima facie case of an equal protection violation.  The District Court's findings of an adverse effect on appellees do not surmount this threshold requirement.  The mere fact that an apportionment scheme makes it more difficult for a particular group in a particular district to elect representatives of its choice does not render that scheme unconstitutional.  A group's electoral power is not unconstitutionally diminished by the fact that an apportionment scheme makes winning elections more difficult
column2: and a failure of proportional representation alone does not constitute impermissible discrimination under the Equal Protection Clause.  As with individual districts
column3: where unconstitutional vote dilution is alleged in the form of statewide political gerrymandering
column5: the mere lack of proportional representation will not be sufficient to prove unconstitutional discrimination.  Without specific supporting evidence
column6: a court cannot presume in such a case that those who are elected will disregard the disproportionally underrepresented group.  Rather
column7: unconstitutional discrimination occurs only when the electoral system is arranged in a manner that will consistently degrade a voter's or a group of voters' influence on the political process as a whole.  The District Court's apparent holding that any interference with an opportunity to elect a representative of one's choice would be sufficient to allege or prove an equal protection violation
column8: unless justified by some acceptable state interest
column9: in addition to being contrary to the above-described conception of an unconstitutional political gerrymander
column10: would invite attack on all or almost all reapportionment statutes.  Pp.  478 U. S. 127-134.

column10: in no way bolsters the contention that there has been a statewide discrimination against Democratic voters.  Pp.  478 U. S. 134-137.

column1: After being charged with violating the Georgia statute criminalizing sodomy by committing that act with another adult male in the bedroom of his home
column2: respondent Hardwick (respondent) brought suit in Federal District Court
column3: challenging the constitutionality of the statute insofar as it criminalized consensual sodomy.  The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.  The Court of Appeals reversed and remanded
column4: holding that the Georgia statute violated respondent's fundamental rights.

column1: Held:  The Georgia statute is constitutional.  Pp.  478 U. S. 190-196.
(a) The Constitution does not confer a fundamental right upon homosexuals to engage in sodomy.  None of the fundamental rights announced in this Court's prior cases involving family relationships
column2: marriage
column3: or procreation bear any resemblance to the right asserted in this case.  And any claim that those cases stand for the proposition that any kind of private sexual conduct between consenting adults is constitutionally insulated from state proscription is unsupportable.  Pp.  478 U. S. 190-191.

column1: (b) Against a background in which many States have criminalized sodomy and still do
column2: to claim that a right to engage in such conduct is ""deeply rooted in this Nation's history and tradition"" or ""implicit in the concept of ordered liberty"" is
column3: at best

column1: (c) There should be great resistance to expand the reach of the Due Process Clauses to cover new fundamental rights.  Otherwise
column2: the Judiciary necessarily would take upon itself further authority to govern the country without constitutional authority.  The claimed right in this case falls far short of overcoming this resistance.  Pp.  478 U. S. 194-195.

column1: Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 prohibits discrimination against handicapped persons in ""any program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance.""  The United States provides financial assistance to airport operators through grants from a Trust Fund under the Airport and Airway Development Act of 1970 and its successor statute
column2: the Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 (Trust Fund Acts).  The Government also operates a nationwide air traffic control system.  Respondent organizations representing handicapped individuals brought an action in the Court of Appeals challenging
column3: inter alia
column4: the conclusion of the Civil Aeronautics Board (CAB) that its regulatory authority under  504 was limited to those few airlines that receive subsidies under the Federal Aviation Act.  The Court of Appeals held that  504 gave CAB jurisdiction over all air carriers by virtue of the extensive program of federal financial assistance to airports under the Trust Fund Acts
column5: and that the air traffic control system was an additional source of financial assistance to airlines.  The court then vacated the regulations to the extent that their application was limited to carriers receiving funds under the Federal Aviation Act
column6: and instructed the Department of Transportation
column7: CAB's successor
column8: to issue new regulations that would apply to all commercial airlines.

column1: Held:  Section 504 is not applicable to commercial airlines.  Pp.  477 U. S. 603-612.

(a) Section 504's scope is limited to those who actually ""receive"" federal financial assistance.  Congress sought to impose  504 coverage as a condition or obligation tied to the recipient's agreement to accept the federal funds.  By so limiting coverage to recipients
column2: Congress imposed  504's obligations upon those who are in a position to accept or reject those obligations as part of the decision whether or not to ""receive"" federal funds.  In this case
column3: the only parties in that position are the airport operators who are the recipients of federal funds under the Trust Fund Acts.  Pp.  477 U. S. 603-606.

column1: (b) To assert that the economic benefit to airlines from the aid to airports is a form of federal financial assistance ignores the distinction that
Congress made in  504 that the statute covers only those who receive the aid
column2: and does not extend to those who benefit from it.  Pp.  477 U. S. 606-607.

column1: (c) To tie  504's scope to economic benefit derived from the Trust Fund expenditures in question here would give  504 almost limitless coverage.  Congress recognized a need to improve airports in order to benefit a wide variety of persons and entities
column2: all of them classified together as beneficiaries
column3: and did not set up a system whereby passengers are the primary or direct beneficiaries and all others
column5: benefited by the Trust Fund Acts are indirect recipients of the financial assistance to airports.  Pp.  477 U. S. 608-610.

column1: (d) The Court of Appeals' attempt to fuse airports and airlines into a single program or activity for purposes of  504 is unavailing.  Regulatory coverage tied to the scope of the intended beneficiaries of the Trust Fund Acts is inconsistent with congressional intent in passing  504.  Pp.  477 U. S. 610-611.
(e) Since the air traffic control system is ""owned and operated"" by the United States
column2: it is not ""Federal financial assistance"" within the meaning of  504.  Rather
column3: it is a federally conducted program that has many beneficiaries
column4: but no recipients.  Pp.  477 U. S. 611-612.

While ineffective assistance of counsel constitutes cause for a procedural default

column2: even if counsel's ignorance or inadvertence does not constitute cause for a procedural default at trial

column5: and the standard for cause should not vary depending on the timing of a procedural default.  The frustration of the State's interests that occurs when an appellate procedural rule is broken is not significantly diminished when counsel's breach results from ignorance or inadvertence

column12: counsel's failure to raise a particular claim on appeal is to be scrutinized under the cause and prejudice standard when that failure is treated as a procedural default by the state courts.  Attorney error short of ineffective assistance of counsel does not constitute cause for a procedural default

column1: Appellee bait dealer (appellee) arranged to have live baitfish imported into Maine
column2: despite a Maine statute prohibiting such importation.  He was indicted under a federal statute making it a federal crime to transport fish in interstate commerce in violation of state law.  He moved to dismiss the indictment on the ground that the Maine statute unconstitutionally burdened interstate commerce
column3: and Maine intervened to defend the validity of its statute.  After an evidentiary hearing
column4: the District Court denied the motion to dismiss and held the state statute constitutional.  The court found that substantial uncertainties surrounded the effects that baitfish parasites and nonnative species would have on the State's wild fish population
column5: and that less discriminatory means of protecting against those threats were currently unavailable.  Appellee then entered a conditional guilty plea
column6: reserving the right to appeal the District Court's constitutional ruling.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column7: concluding that the state statute was unconstitutional.

column1: 1. Maine is entitled to invoke this Court's jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C.  1254(2).  Nothing in the language or history of  1254(2) suggests that its scope is limited to civil litigation.  The fact that Maine was only an intervenor in the District Court does not deprive it of standing to pursue this appeal
column2: because its stake in the outcome is substantial and the controversy remains live
column3: notwithstanding the Federal Government's decision to abandon its own appeal.  Pp.  477 U. S. 133-137.

column1: 2. The Maine statute is constitutional.  The federal statute under which appellee was convicted did not waive the requirement of Hughes v. Oklahoma
column3: that where a state statute
column5: discriminates against interstate commerce either on its face or in practical effect
column6: the State must show both that the statute serves a legitimate local purpose
column7: and that this purpose cannot be served as well by available nondiscriminatory means.  But the evidence amply supports the District Court's findings that Maine has made both showings.  Under the ""clearly erroneous"" standard of review applicable to these findings
column8: the Court of Appeals erred in setting them aside.  Pp.  477 U. S. 137-152.
